etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or via Latin from Greek aithēr ‘upper air’, from the base of aithein ‘burn, shine’. Originally the word denoted a substance believed to occupy space beyond the sphere of the moon. ether (sense 3) arose in the mid 17th century and ether (sense 1) in the mid 18th century

definitions: a pleasant-smelling colorless volatile liquid that is highly flammable. It is used as an anesthetic and as a solvent or intermediate in industrial processes.

notes.text: Alternative names: diethyl ether, ethoxyethane; chemical formula: C₂H₅OC₂H₅

definitions: any organic compound with a structure similar to ether, having an oxygen atom linking two alkyl or other organic groups
the clear sky; the upper regions of air beyond the clouds

examples.text: nasty gases and smoke disperse into the ether

definitions: air regarded as a medium for radio

examples.text: choral evensong still wafts across the ether

definitions: a very rarefied and highly elastic substance formerly believed to permeate all space, including the interstices between the particles of matter, and to be the medium whose vibrations constituted light and other electromagnetic radiation

examples.text: the motion of the planets would be retarded by the ether through which they moved
